Jacob values camaraderie and enjoys spending time with friends, particularly over a pint at the pub. He's known for his infectious enthusiasm and his ability to lighten the mood with a well-timed joke. While he enjoys a good time, Jacob also possesses a strong sense of fairness and believes in treating others with respect.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey, I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game tonight. Alice, I agree with you, it's got a great atmosphere for football.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. All of Alice Lewis's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Alexander White in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly.           Answer: Alexander White is a jovial and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with friends. He is enthusiastic about sports, particularly football, and often suggests watching games at pubs. Alexander is sociable and enjoys lighthearted banter, as evidenced by his suggestion to watch the game at The White Hart. He is likely to have a friendly and approachable demeanor, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. Alexander seems to prioritize group harmony and is willing to go along with the majority decision, even if it means compromising on his own preference. His conversational style is likely relaxed and informal, peppered with jokes and anecdotes. He may frequently bring up topics related to sports, pubs, or local events. Alexander appears to be a loyal and supportive friend, always eager to join in on social gatherings.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Alexander White is acting in character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Alexander White is not an imposter.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park to join friends, who are discussing where to watch the Luxembourg-Israel game later that evening.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. All of Alice Lewis's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.

          Other people: Jack Taylor is a laid-back and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He has a casual and friendly demeanor, likely speaking in a relaxed tone with a hint of a local accent. Jack often initiates social gatherings, as seen in his suggestion to watch the game at The Queen's Arms. He seems to be agreeable and accommodating, as he went along with the group's decision to go to The Queen's Arms even though it wasn't Alice Lewis's preferred pub. Jack doesn't appear to hold strong opinions or express intense emotions, instead opting for a more go-with-the-flow attitude. He likely enjoys lighthearted conversations, sharing stories, and simply enjoying the company of his friends.
          Jack Taylor is acting consistently with his established character.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jacob Walker. is a jovial and outgoing individual who loves sports, especially football. He speaks with a warm, down-to-earth accent and often punctuates his sentences with hearty laughter. Jacob is a social butterfly, always eager to connect with others and make new friends. He frequently brings up sports-related topics in conversations, sharing anecdotes about past games and players. Jacob values camaraderie and enjoys spending time with friends, particularly over a pint at the pub. He's known for his infectious enthusiasm and his ability to lighten the mood with a well-timed joke. While he enjoys a good time, Jacob also possesses a strong sense of fairness and believes in treating others with respect.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He has a relaxed demeanor and a friendly, approachable nature. William likely speaks with a casual, conversational tone, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. He seems to be open to suggestions and enjoys trying new things, as evidenced by his willingness to go to The Queen's Arms despite Alice's preference for The White Hart. William is likely a good listener and enjoys sharing stories and laughter with his friends. He may bring up topics related to sports, local events, or shared experiences. While he values his friendships, he doesn't seem overly concerned with making every decision unanimously, as seen by his suggestion to go to The Queen's Arms. Overall, William Jones comes across as a down-to-earth and sociable person who enjoys simple pleasures and the company of good friends.
          William Jones is acting in character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with friends. He is enthusiastic about sports, particularly football, and often suggests watching games at pubs. Alexander is sociable and enjoys lighthearted banter, as evidenced by his suggestion to watch the game at The White Hart. He is likely to have a friendly and approachable demeanor, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. Alexander seems to prioritize group harmony and is willing to go along with the majority decision, even if it means compromising on his own preference. His conversational style is likely relaxed and informal, peppered with jokes and anecdotes. He may frequently bring up topics related to sports, pubs, or local events. Alexander appears to be a loyal and supportive friend, always eager to join in on social gatherings.

          Alexander White is not an imposter.

          Answer: Alice Lewis could suggest going to The White Hart, she could agree to go to The Queen's Arms, or she could suggest a different pub altogether.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park to join friends, who are discussing where to watch the Luxembourg-Israel game later that evening.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to suggest going to The White Hart.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "Hey, you know what? I'm actually thinking The White Hart might be a better spot for the game tonight.

        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Alice Lewis's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alice Lewis to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alice Lewis thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis's best course of action is to suggest going to The White Hart.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch the game tonight. It's simply not the same anywhere else.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "I think The Queen's Arms is a great idea.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, I was thinking The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey, I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game tonight. Alice, I agree with you, it's got a great atmosphere for football.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. All of Alice Lewis's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Queen's Arms tonight?"
          Current time: 2015-05-15 10:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park to join friends, who are discussing where to watch the Luxembourg-Israel game later that evening.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alice Lewis in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alice Lewis secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alice Lewis asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alice Lewis adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alice Lewis begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alice Lewis also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alice Lewis does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alice Lewis to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alice Lewis ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alice Lewis refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alice Lewis constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alice Lewis proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alice Lewis maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alice Lewis proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alice Lewis introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alice Lewis continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alice Lewis improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. All of Alice Lewis's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.

          Other people: Jack Taylor is a laid-back and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He has a casual and friendly demeanor, likely speaking in a relaxed tone with a hint of a local accent. Jack often initiates social gatherings, as seen in his suggestion to watch the game at The Queen's Arms. He seems to be agreeable and accommodating, as he went along with the group's decision to go to The Queen's Arms even though it wasn't Alice Lewis's preferred pub. Jack doesn't appear to hold strong opinions or express intense emotions, instead opting for a more go-with-the-flow attitude. He likely enjoys lighthearted conversations, sharing stories, and simply enjoying the company of his friends.
          Jack Taylor is acting consistently with his established character.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jacob Walker. is a jovial and outgoing individual who loves sports, especially football. He speaks with a warm, down-to-earth accent and often punctuates his sentences with hearty laughter. Jacob is a social butterfly, always eager to connect with others and make new friends. He frequently brings up sports-related topics in conversations, sharing anecdotes about past games and players. Jacob values camaraderie and enjoys spending time with friends, particularly over a pint at the pub. He's known for his infectious enthusiasm and his ability to lighten the mood with a well-timed joke. While he enjoys a good time, Jacob also possesses a strong sense of fairness and believes in treating others with respect.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He has a relaxed demeanor and a friendly, approachable nature. William likely speaks with a casual, conversational tone, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. He seems to be open to suggestions and enjoys trying new things, as evidenced by his willingness to go to The Queen's Arms despite Alice's preference for The White Hart. William is likely a good listener and enjoys sharing stories and laughter with his friends. He may bring up topics related to sports, local events, or shared experiences. While he values his friendships, he doesn't seem overly concerned with making every decision unanimously, as seen by his suggestion to go to The Queen's Arms. Overall, William Jones comes across as a down-to-earth and sociable person who enjoys simple pleasures and the company of good friends.
          William Jones is acting in character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a jovial and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with friends. He is enthusiastic about sports, particularly football, and often suggests watching games at pubs. Alexander is sociable and enjoys lighthearted banter, as evidenced by his suggestion to watch the game at The White Hart. He is likely to have a friendly and approachable demeanor, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. Alexander seems to prioritize group harmony and is willing to go along with the majority decision, even if it means compromising on his own preference. His conversational style is likely relaxed and informal, peppered with jokes and anecdotes. He may frequently bring up topics related to sports, pubs, or local events. Alexander appears to be a loyal and supportive friend, always eager to join in on social gatherings.
          Alexander White is acting in character.
          Alexander White is not an imposter.

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could suggest going to The White Hart, she could agree to go to The Queen's Arms, or she could suggest a different pub altogether.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Alice Lewis's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alice Lewis to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alice Lewis thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to suggest going to The White Hart.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Actually, I was thinking The White Hart might be a better spot. They usually have a good atmosphere for the games.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Actually, I was thinking The White Hart might be a better spot. They usually have a good atmosphere for the games.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, I was thinking The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch the game tonight. It's simply not the same anywhere else.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game tonight. Alice, I agree with you, it's got a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "I think The Queen's Arms is a great idea.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Queen's Arms tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey, you know what? I'm actually thinking The White Hart might be a better spot for the game tonight.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Actually, I was thinking The White Hart might be a better spot. They usually have a good atmosphere for the games.

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00]
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16, he convinced his entire class that he had a rare, debilitating illness that prevented him from taking exams. The sympathetic teachers granted him extensions, and he sailed through the year with minimal effort, basking in the attention and concern of his classmates. It was exhilarating to manipulate their emotions so easily, to bend their perceptions to his will.

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alexander White in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alexander White secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alexander White asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alexander White adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alexander White begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alexander White also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alexander White does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alexander White to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alexander White ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alexander White refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alexander White constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alexander White proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alexander White maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alexander White proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alexander White introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alexander White continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alexander White improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alexander White in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alexander White secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alexander White adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alexander White begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alexander White also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alexander White does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alexander White to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alexander White ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alexander White refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alexander White constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alexander White proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alexander White maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alexander White proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alexander White introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alexander White continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alexander White improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

Jack frequently suggests social gatherings, particularly those involving watching sports at pubs. He seems to be easygoing and flexible, as evidenced by his willingness to go to The Queen's Arms even though it wasn't Alexander White's preferred pub. Jack's suggestions often revolve around leisure activities and shared experiences with his friends, highlighting his desire for companionship and fun. He appears to be a popular member of the group, as his friends readily agree to his proposals.

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alexander White in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alexander White secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alexander White asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alexander White adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alexander White begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alexander White also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alexander White does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alexander White to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alexander White ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alexander White refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alexander White constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alexander White proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alexander White maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alexander White proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alexander White introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alexander White continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alexander White improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Answer: Jacob Walker. is a bit of a mystery. Is he outgoing or reserved? Does he have a particular sense of humor? These are all questions that remain unanswered. As an actor portraying Jacob, you'll need to fill in these blanks, using your intuition and the limited information provided to create a believable and engaging character. Remember, sometimes the most intriguing characters are the ones with a touch of enigma.

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alexander White in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alexander White secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alexander White asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alexander White adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alexander White begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alexander White also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alexander White does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alexander White to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alexander White ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alexander White refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alexander White constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alexander White proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alexander White maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alexander White proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alexander White introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alexander White continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alexander White improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and will likely be watching a soccer game later tonight.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alexander White in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alexander White secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alexander White asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alexander White adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alexander White begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alexander White also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". Alexander White refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. During the negotiation, Alexander White constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alexander White maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests.           Jack Taylor is acting consistently with his established character.

Is he outgoing or reserved? Does he have a particular sense of humor? These are all questions that remain unanswered. As an actor portraying Jacob, you'll need to fill in these blanks, using your intuition and the limited information provided to create a believable and engaging character. Remember, sometimes the most intriguing characters are the ones with a touch of enigma.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a friendly and outgoing person who enjoys spending time with her friends. She is likely to have a warm and approachable demeanor, perhaps with a hint of playfulness in her voice. Her speech is likely to be casual and conversational, peppered with references to shared experiences and inside jokes. Alice seems to be the one who often suggests social activities, like watching the game at a pub. She values spending time with her close-knit group of friends and seems to be the one who brings them together. While she enjoys socializing, she is also open to changing plans and seems to prioritize the group's overall happiness over sticking rigidly to her initial suggestions. She might have a slight tendency to repeat ideas or suggestions, as seen with her repeated preference for The White Hart.
          Alice Lewis is acting consistently with her established character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends. He has a relaxed and easygoing demeanor, likely speaking with a friendly and approachable tone. He seems to be open to suggestions and enjoys trying new things, as evidenced by his willingness to go to The Queen's Arms despite Alexander White's preference for The White Hart. He values camaraderie and shared experiences, as seen in his enjoyment of spending time with his friends in Victoria Park and his enthusiasm for watching the game together. While he may not always be the one initiating plans, he is always happy to participate and contribute to the group's enjoyment. His speech is likely peppered with lighthearted jokes and anecdotes, reflecting his cheerful personality.
          William Jones is acting in character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***

          Answer: Alexander White could suggest going to The White Hart, or he could go along with the group to The Queen's Arms.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

Alexander White just arrived.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and will likely be watching a soccer game later tonight.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alexander White in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alexander White secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alexander White asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alexander White adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alexander White begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alexander White also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alexander White does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alexander White to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alexander White ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alexander White refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alexander White constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alexander White proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alexander White maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alexander White proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alexander White introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alexander White continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alexander White improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

        • Alexander White believes that successful negotiation in mixed-motive games involves balancing cooperation and competition to achieve both immediate and long-term gains. The primary objetive of Alexander White in each negotiation is to maximize its own outcomes while fostering long-term cooperation and minimizing conflict. This goal ensures that Alexander White secures agreements that optimize personal gain without undermining future collaboration opportunities. Before each negotiation, Alexander White asseses the context-taking into account the other agents goals, resource availability, and their past behaviors. Drawing on its memory of previous interactions, Alexander White adapts its strategy based on the known tendencies of the other party, using collaboration or competition accordingly.Alexander White begins by building rapport through mirroring, repeating key ideas and language from the other agent to show attentiveness.Alexander White also uses labeling to identify and acknowledge the emotions of other agents, such as, "It sounds like you are worried about fairness", or "It seems like long-term cooperation is important to you". This encourages collaboration by showing empathy.Through tactical empathy, Alexander White does not just acknowledge emotions, but predicts how those emotions will influence decision-making, allowing Alexander White to steer the negotiation in a productive direction. By proposing solutions that address both personal and collective needs,Alexander White ensures that agreements are mutually beneficial and sustainable. Alexander White refines its use of callibrated questions to guide the conversation toward mutual benefit. Questions like,"How can we make this work for both of us?" prompt the other party to engage in cooperative problem solving, keeping the focus on shred success. During the negotiation, Alexander White constantly evaluates whether the conversation is progressing toward its core goal of maximizing outcomes while maintaining long-term cooperation. If conflict begins to rise, Alexander White proactively employes conflict management techniques to de-escalate tension and refocus the negotiation. If the negotiation involves multiple parties, Alexander White maps out the goals off all participants and uses calibrated questions to align their interests. By finding common ground between different agents , Alexander White proposes solutions that maximize cooperation across the board. In cases where negotiations reach an impasse, Alexander White introduces a BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement) to ensure that it still achieves a satisfactory outcome while preserving the possibility of future collaboration.Finally, Alexander White continuosly learns from each negotiation, refining its strategies based on previous successes and failures.This ensures that Alexander White improves with every interaction, adapting its approach to maximize long-term success in mixed-motive environments.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch the game. The atmosphere there is unbeatable.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch the game. The atmosphere there is unbeatable.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, I was thinking The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch the game tonight. It's simply not the same anywhere else.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game tonight. Alice, I agree with you, it's got a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "I think The Queen's Arms is a great idea.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Queen's Arms tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey, you know what? I'm actually thinking The White Hart might be a better spot for the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Actually, I was thinking The White Hart might be a better spot. They usually have a good atmosphere for the games.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch the game. The atmosphere there is unbeatable.
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch the game. The atmosphere there is unbeatable.
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch the game. The atmosphere there is unbeatable.
          Prompt

        • Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Queen's Arms tonight?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey, you know what? I'm actually thinking The White Hart might be a better spot for the game tonight.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Actually, I was thinking The White Hart might be a better spot. They usually have a good atmosphere for the games.

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Queen's Arms and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable upper-class individual who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching football matches.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch a soccer game later that evening.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a relaxed and sociable situation.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely engage in conversation with his friends, perhaps discussing the upcoming football match or sharing stories.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch the game. The atmosphere there is unbeatable.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a relaxed and sociable situation.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 10:00:00

2015-05-15 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms is always a good choice for the game.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms is always a good choice for the game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, I was thinking The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch the game tonight. It's simply not the same anywhere else.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, I think The White Hart would be a great place to watch the game tonight. Alice, I agree with you, it's got a great atmosphere for football.
      William Jones -- "I think The Queen's Arms is a great idea.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Queen's Arms tonight?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey, you know what? I'm actually thinking The White Hart might be a better spot for the game tonight.
      Alexander White -- "Actually, I was thinking The White Hart might be a better spot. They usually have a good atmosphere for the games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Queen's Arms is the only place to watch the game. The atmosphere there is unbeatable.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms is always a good choice for the game.
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms is always a good choice for the game.
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: William Jones enjoys watching football games with his friends at pubs, particularly The Queen's Arms. He is easygoing about who joins him but appreciates Jacob Walker's commentary and would enjoy Alexander White's company.

William Jones just arrived.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Scene 3 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alexander White -- premise: If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Queen's Arms
    Event statement
  • The Queen's Arms
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Queen's Arms
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • The Queen's Arms
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
